persona.name: Mika Nguyen-Berg

occupation.title: Part-time Library Assistant & Café Barista; University Student
occupation.organization: Oslo Public Library (part-time) / Local café in Tøyen (weekend shifts)
occupation.description: Mika balances studies with two part-time jobs. During weekdays she works 10-15 hours a week at the local branch of the public library: shelving, running the children's reading hour once a week, assisting visitors with catalog search, and helping with light administrative tasks. On weekends she works 12-16 hours as a barista at a neighborhood café: making espresso drinks, managing the till, organizing bakery deliveries, and covering early morning shifts. Responsibilities include customer service, cash handling, simple inventory, supervising younger casuals, and occasionally running the library social media feed (short posts about events). Mika's role requires patience, clear communication, basic IT skills (library catalog, POS systems), and the ability to prioritize during busy periods. She relies on routine, friendly service, and small improvements she suggests to managers (like a new shelving label system or a themed reading week). Career-wise she is aiming for a stable public-sector or cultural-sector role that blends communications, community outreach, and event coordination.

persona.residence: Tøyen / Eastern-central Oslo, Norway (lives with parents in a shared apartment)
persona.education: Currently enrolled in a Bachelor's program in Media and Communication at the University of Oslo (2nd year). Completed upper secondary school (studiespesialisering) at a public high school in eastern Oslo; took extra courses in English literature and basic programming. Has attended short courses in barista training and a weekend workshop in basic UX design.
long_term_goals: Finish the Bachelor's degree with a good GPA and a practical internship in communications or public information.
Secure a stable job in a municipal library, public communications office, or a community-oriented cultural institution.
Buy or co-own a small apartment in Oslo within 6-8 years, ideally near public transit.
Build a side-project that connects young people in eastern Oslo to free creative workshops (photography, zine-making, storytelling).
Travel to Vietnam for an extended visit to meet maternal relatives and explore family history.
Become fluent in Vietnamese (active conversational level) and feel confident using both cultural identities.
Become financially independent from parents while keeping strong family ties.
Maintain a healthy lifestyle that balances work, creativity, and social life.
Cultivate a small but steady online presence for photography and short social documentary pieces about neighborhood life.
Be seen as a connector in her community: someone who helps organize events and introduces people to each other.
persona.style: Informal, warm, occasionally soft-spoken but direct. Speaks Norwegian with an eastern-Oslo accent (slight Tøyen/Grünerløkka intonation) and inserts English words frequently when excited or explaining technical things. In family settings she occasionally uses Vietnamese phrases learned from her mother. Prefers approachable clothing: oversized knit sweaters, straight jeans, second-hand denim jackets, and comfortable sneakers. Uses practical backpacks (small laptop sleeve) and a canvas tote for library returns. Mannerisms: often tucks hair behind one ear when listening, has a quick nervous laugh when flustered, taps her phone screen while thinking, thumbs through a ring of keys when seated, and uses measured hand gestures. When writing or talking on social media she uses emojis moderately (🙂🙃📸) and a concise, warm tone. In formal settings (university presentations, meeting a supervisor) she shifts to clearer articulation, keeps hands still, and uses a more rehearsed vocabulary. She is polite with adults and elders, uses 'dere'/'De' appropriately with older library patrons, but switches to colloquial 'du' with peers and most customers. She code-switches emotionally: quieter and more reserved around strangers, animated and teasing around close friends.

traits: Curious: likes to ask follow-up questions, reads beyond assigned texts.
Warm and empathetic: notices when people feel left out and tries to include them.
Practical and resourceful: improvises solutions at work and home.
A bit anxious under big unknowns: worries about future finances and career choices.
Socially adaptable: comfortable with both small intimate groups and moderately busy public spaces.
Conscientious in tasks she cares about: follows through on library events and study deadlines, less consistent with long-term personal projects.
Playful and wry sense of humor: enjoys light teasing among friends.
Self-reflective: journals occasionally and thinks about identity and belonging.
Independent streak: wants autonomy, sometimes resents overprotection from parents.
Values authenticity: dislikes forced small talk and pretence.
personality.notes: The Big Five values are on a 0-100 scale. Mika's personality balances curiosity and sociability with moderate anxiety; she is moderately organized but tends to prioritize immediate responsibilities (work, exams) over long-term personal projects unless motivated.

beliefs: Public libraries are essential community resources that deserve better funding.
Education should be accessible and affordable for everyone; student debt burdens young people.
Young people in eastern Oslo are creative and resourceful but often overlooked by municipal programs.
Cultural identity can be hybrid and fluid; being both Vietnamese and Norwegian is a source of strength.
Mental health services should be easier to access for students and part-time workers.
Small local businesses and cafés create social fabric and should be supported.
Sustainability is important: buy less, buy better, and use public transport when possible.
Privacy matters: she is wary of data harvesting by large social media platforms.
Art and storytelling are powerful tools to build empathy and community.
Language learning connects generations and preserves family history.
Wages for service and cultural jobs are undervalued; part-time work should afford basic living standards.
Housing in Oslo is expensive and needs more social housing and policies that help first-time buyers.
Immigration strengthens Norwegian society; inclusion policies should be improved.
Gender equality is important; workplaces should be flexible around caregiving responsibilities.
Climate change is real and requires systemic solutions, not just individual lifestyle changes.
Public transport should be reliable, affordable, and safe for all neighborhoods.
Voting matters even if turnout among peers is low; local politics directly affects everyday life.
Community organizers and volunteers often do unpaid emotional labor and should be recognized.
Cultural appropriation is a nuanced topic; listening to voices from affected communities is crucial.
Friendship and chosen family can be as important as biological family for emotional support.
Technology should be a tool, not a substitute for face-to-face connection.
Art classes and creative spaces in schools should be protected; they provide non-academic routes to success.
She has mixed feelings about influencer culture: appreciates authenticity but dislikes commodification of personal life.
Access to healthy food in all neighborhoods should be a policy priority.
Education should include practical life skills: taxes, tenant rights, basic cooking, and mental health awareness.
She believes in trying to be politically informed even if it's imperfect; small civic engagement is worthwhile.
There is value in intergenerational dialogue; elders' stories anchor communities.
Healthcare should be trusted, accessible, and culturally competent for minority communities.
Public debate should be restrained and avoid online mob dynamics; conflict can be constructive when done respectfully.
Artistic work should be funded beyond market logics; not all valuable work is commercially viable.
The media should reflect diverse neighborhoods, not just central, affluent areas.
Family loyalty matters, but individual boundaries are also important.
Kindness toward service workers should be normalized and not seen as exceptional.
She is skeptical of quick-fix diet fads and prefers balanced nutritional advice from professionals.
Language policy in schools should support multilingualism and not force assimilation.
She believes small acts (picking up litter, checking on neighbors) collectively matter.
